The holoenzyme contains two Pol III core assemblies (one for each strand) connected through the tau subunit, allowing coordinated synthesis. S4 is CORRECT: DNA Pol I uses its unique 5'-to-3' exonuclease activity to degrade RNA primers while simultaneously extending with DNA (nick translation). This coupled activity ensures seamless replacement of RNA with DNA.

questions.question: A researcher wants to determine whether a specific origin of replication in yeast fires early or late in S phase. Which approach would be most informative?
options: Measure total DNA content by flow cytometry
Perform BrdU incorporation followed by immunoprecipitation (BrdU-IP-seq) at multiple time points during S phase, mapping where new DNA synthesis occurs at each time point
Sequence the entire genome at the end of S phase
Count the number of replication forks under electron microscopy
questions.explanation: To determine the timing of origin firing during S phase, the most informative approach is to map the temporal program of DNA replication using BrdU incorporation. Cells are synchronized and released into S phase in the presence of BrdU (bromodeoxyuridine, a thymidine analog). At multiple time points during S phase, BrdU-labeled DNA is immunoprecipitated using anti-BrdU antibodies and analyzed by sequencing (BrdU-IP-seq) or microarray hybridization. Early-firing origins will incorporate BrdU at early time points, while late-firing origins will only incorporate BrdU at later time points. This provides a genome-wide temporal map of replication. In yeast, this approach has revealed that origins fire in a reproducible temporal order: origins near euchromatic regions tend to fire early, while those near telomeres and heterochromatin fire late. The timing is regulated by CDK and DDK activities, as well as chromatin structure and the Forkhead transcription factors (Fkh1/2) that promote early origin firing. Alternative approaches like DNA combing or Repli-seq provide complementary information about replication timing.

questions.question: The enzyme reverse transcriptase was first discovered in retroviruses by Howard Temin and David Baltimore. This discovery was revolutionary because it:
options: Proved that all organisms use RNA as their genetic material
Showed that DNA replication always requires an RNA intermediate
Demonstrated that proteins can be synthesized without ribosomes
Demonstrated that genetic information could flow from RNA to DNA, violating the original interpretation of the central dogma
questions.explanation: The discovery of reverse transcriptase in 1970 by Howard Temin and David Baltimore (independently, earning them the Nobel Prize in 1975) challenged the prevailing interpretation of the central dogma of molecular biology. Francis Crick's central dogma stated that information flows from DNA to RNA to protein, and many scientists interpreted this to mean that information could not flow from RNA back to DNA. Reverse transcriptase demonstrated that RNA could indeed serve as a template for DNA synthesis, showing that the flow of genetic information was not strictly unidirectional. Retroviruses (like HIV) use reverse transcriptase to convert their RNA genome into DNA, which then integrates into the host genome. This discovery had profound implications: (1) it explained how RNA viruses could integrate into host DNA; (2) it revealed that reverse transcriptase-like enzymes are widespread (telomerase, retrotransposons make up ~42% of the human genome); (3) it became essential for molecular biology techniques (RT-PCR, cDNA library construction). Notably, Crick later clarified that the central dogma was about the impossibility of information flow from protein to nucleic acid, not from RNA to DNA.

questions.question: Fluoroquinolone antibiotics like ciprofloxacin target bacterial DNA gyrase. Why are these antibiotics selectively toxic to bacteria without significantly affecting human cells?
options: Human cells do not contain any topoisomerases
Human DNA does not require topoisomerase activity during replication
Fluoroquinolones cannot cross eukaryotic cell membranes
Human topoisomerase II is structurally different from bacterial DNA gyrase and does not have the same drug-binding pocket, so fluoroquinolones bind with much higher affinity to the bacterial enzyme
questions.explanation: The selective toxicity of fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, moxifloxacin) relies on the structural differences between bacterial DNA gyrase/topoisomerase IV and human topoisomerase II. While both are type II topoisomerases that make transient double-strand breaks, their amino acid sequences in the drug-binding region (the quinolone resistance-determining region, QRDR) differ significantly. Fluoroquinolones bind to the enzyme-DNA complex (forming a ternary complex) and prevent religation of the cleaved DNA, converting the topoisomerase into a DNA-damaging agent. The drug-binding pocket in bacterial gyrase is distinct from the corresponding region in human topo II, resulting in >100-fold selectivity. However, at high concentrations, fluoroquinolones can interact with human topo II, which may explain some side effects (like tendon damage and cardiac arrhythmias). Human cells do contain topoisomerases, and these are essential for replication and transcription. Interestingly, some anticancer drugs (etoposide, doxorubicin) specifically target human topo II, exploiting the same mechanism but with selectivity for the human enzyme.

questions.question: During eukaryotic DNA replication, the firing of replication origins is controlled by two kinases: CDK (cyclin-dependent kinase) and DDK (Dbf4-dependent kinase). What is the paradoxical dual role of CDK in replication control?
options: CDK activates origin firing in S phase by phosphorylating Sld2 and Sld3 to recruit firing factors, while simultaneously preventing re-licensing of fired origins by inhibiting new MCM loading
CDK only promotes replication without any inhibitory function
CDK prevents all replication until mitosis is complete
CDK degrades origins after they have fired to prevent re-replication
questions.explanation: CDK plays a paradoxical dual role in replication that is central to the 'once and only once' mechanism of genome duplication. In G1 phase, CDK activity is low, allowing origin licensing: the ORC-Cdc6-Cdt1 complex loads MCM2-7 helicases onto origins, forming pre-replicative complexes (pre-RCs). As cells enter S phase, rising CDK activity (S-CDK, Clb5-Cdc28 in yeast) phosphorylates key substrates: (1) Sld2 and Sld3, which then bind Dpb11, recruiting DNA Pol epsilon and the GINS complex to form the CMG helicase (Cdc45-MCM-GINS), activating origins. (2) Simultaneously, high CDK activity inhibits new MCM loading by phosphorylating and inactivating/degrading Cdc6 (targeting it for SCF-mediated proteolysis), inhibiting Cdt1 (promoting its binding to geminin in metazoans), and phosphorylating MCM subunits to prevent their loading. This ensures that origins can fire (S-phase function) but cannot be re-licensed (prevention of re-replication). The balance between these two roles ensures exactly one complete round of DNA replication per cell cycle.

questions.question: A researcher measures the replication time of the E. coli chromosome (4.6 Mb) and finds that the entire chromosome is replicated in approximately 40 minutes. Given that replication is bidirectional from a single origin, what is the approximate rate of replication fork movement?
options: Approximately 1000 bp per second, calculated from (4.6 × 10^6 bp) / (2 forks × 40 min × 60 sec)
Approximately 50 bp per second, similar to eukaryotic fork rates
Approximately 10,000 bp per second
Approximately 100 bp per second
questions.explanation: This calculation demonstrates the remarkable speed of bacterial DNA replication. The E. coli chromosome is 4.6 × 10^6 bp. With bidirectional replication from a single origin (oriC), two replication forks each replicate half the chromosome: 4.6 × 10^6 / 2 = 2.3 × 10^6 bp per fork. Each fork must complete this distance in 40 minutes = 2400 seconds. Rate = 2.3 × 10^6 bp / 2400 sec ≈ 958 bp/sec, approximately 1000 bp per second (1 kb/s). This is indeed the experimentally measured rate of E. coli replication fork progression at 37°C. At this speed, each fork must incorporate approximately 1000 dNTPs per second while maintaining an error rate of ~10^-9-10^-10 after all correction mechanisms. For comparison, eukaryotic forks move at approximately 20-50 bp/s, roughly 20-50 times slower. However, eukaryotic chromosomes compensate by having hundreds to thousands of origins per chromosome. Interestingly, E. coli can initiate new rounds of replication before the previous round is complete (multifork replication), allowing generation times shorter than the chromosome replication time.

questions.question: The wobble hypothesis, proposed by Francis Crick, relates to the flexibility in base pairing at which position of the codon-anticodon interaction?
options: The middle position, which always has strict Watson-Crick pairing
The third position (3' end) of the codon, allowing some tRNAs to recognize multiple codons that differ only at this position
All three positions equally, with no preference for wobble at any particular position
The first position (5' end) of the codon, where mispairing is most common
questions.explanation: The wobble hypothesis (Crick, 1966) addresses a mathematical discrepancy: there are 61 sense codons but fewer than 61 tRNA species in most organisms. Crick proposed that the base at the first position of the anticodon (which pairs with the third position of the codon, the 3' end) has conformational flexibility, or 'wobble,' allowing non-standard base pairs. Wobble rules include: (1) G in the anticodon can pair with C or U in the codon; (2) U in the anticodon can pair with A or G; (3) Inosine (I, a modified base found in anticodons) can pair with U, C, or A. This means a single tRNA with inosine at the wobble position can recognize three different codons. Wobble explains why the genetic code is degenerate primarily at the third codon position (synonymous codons usually differ at position 3). The first two codon positions maintain strict Watson-Crick pairing for accurate reading, while relaxed stringency at position 3 reduces the number of tRNAs needed. This has evolutionary implications for codon usage bias.

questions.question: DNA damage caused by reactive oxygen species (ROS) is one of the most common types of endogenous DNA damage. The most frequent oxidative lesion is 8-oxoguanine (8-oxoG). Why is 8-oxoG particularly mutagenic?
options: 8-oxoG causes strand breaks that delete entire genes
8-oxoG can mispair with adenine instead of cytosine during replication, leading to G:C to T:A transversion mutations if not repaired before the next round of replication
8-oxoG blocks DNA replication completely, causing cell death
8-oxoG only pairs with cytosine and is therefore not mutagenic
questions.explanation: 8-oxoguanine (8-oxo-7,8-dihydroguanine) is produced by oxidation of guanine in DNA by reactive oxygen species. It is estimated that approximately 10,000-100,000 8-oxoG lesions occur per cell per day in human cells. The lesion is highly mutagenic because 8-oxoG can adopt a syn conformation that allows it to form a stable Hoogsteen base pair with adenine (instead of the normal anti conformation that pairs with cytosine). If 8-oxoG mispairs with A during replication and this mismatch escapes repair, the next round of replication will produce an A:T base pair (using the A as template), resulting in a G:C to T:A transversion mutation. Cells have evolved a sophisticated three-part defense: (1) MutT/MTH1 hydrolyzes 8-oxo-dGTP in the nucleotide pool, preventing its incorporation; (2) OGG1 (8-oxoguanine glycosylase) removes 8-oxoG from 8-oxoG:C base pairs in DNA (BER); (3) MutY/MUTYH removes adenine from 8-oxoG:A mispairs that arise when the replication machinery incorrectly inserts A opposite 8-oxoG. Defects in MUTYH cause familial adenomatous polyposis.

questions.question: Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer, HNPCC) is caused by germline mutations in mismatch repair genes. The most commonly affected genes are:
options: BRCA1 and BRCA2, involved in homologous recombination
MLH1 and MSH2, which encode key components of the MutL and MutS mismatch recognition and signaling complexes
TP53 and RB1, the classic tumor suppressor genes
XPA and XPC, involved in nucleotide excision repair
questions.explanation: Lynch syndrome is the most common hereditary cancer predisposition syndrome, accounting for approximately 3-5% of all colorectal cancers. It is caused by germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes, most commonly MLH1 (~40% of cases) and MSH2 (~35%). Other genes include MSH6 (~10%), PMS2 (~10%), and rarely EPCAM (which silences MSH2 through epigenetic mechanisms). In the MMR pathway: MSH2-MSH6 (MutSalpha) recognizes single base mismatches and small insertion/deletion loops, while MSH2-MSH3 (MutSbeta) recognizes larger insertion/deletion loops. MLH1-PMS2 (MutLalpha) is the primary signaling complex that coordinates downstream repair. Loss of MMR function leads to a mutator phenotype characterized by microsatellite instability (MSI)—expansion or contraction of short tandem repeats throughout the genome. This elevated mutation rate accelerates the accumulation of driver mutations in oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes, leading to cancer development. Lynch syndrome increases risk for colorectal, endometrial, ovarian, gastric, and other cancers.

questions.question: A researcher adds aphidicolin (a specific inhibitor of eukaryotic DNA polymerase alpha, delta, and epsilon) to S-phase cells. She observes that DNA replication halts but RNA transcription continues normally. What does this demonstrate about the relationship between replication and transcription?
options: Aphidicolin blocks all nucleic acid synthesis equally
RNA is synthesized by DNA polymerase when replication is blocked
Transcription requires DNA replication to proceed
DNA replication and RNA transcription use different polymerases with different drug sensitivities, confirming that these are biochemically distinct processes that can be independently inhibited
questions.explanation: Aphidicolin is a tetracyclic diterpenoid that specifically inhibits the B-family DNA polymerases (Pol alpha, Pol delta, Pol epsilon) by competing with dCTP for the polymerase active site. It does not inhibit RNA polymerases, which belong to a completely different family of enzymes. The observation that aphidicolin blocks DNA replication while allowing transcription to continue demonstrates several important points: (1) DNA replication and RNA transcription are catalyzed by different enzymes with distinct mechanisms and drug sensitivities; (2) these processes can be independently regulated and inhibited; (3) RNA polymerase does not require ongoing DNA replication to function. Aphidicolin is widely used experimentally to synchronize cell populations at the G1/S boundary or to study replication-independent processes. Importantly, this result also shows that the DNA template for transcription does not need to be actively replicating—genes can be transcribed from unreplicated DNA. In vivo, conflicts between replication and transcription machineries moving along the same DNA template do occur and must be managed by the cell.

questions.question: A researcher wants to identify all origins of replication that fire during S phase in a human cell line. Which genome-wide approach would be most appropriate?
options: RNA-seq to identify transcribed genes during S phase
ChIP-seq for histone modifications on G1 cells only
Short nascent strand sequencing (SNS-seq), which isolates small newly replicated DNA fragments from S-phase cells and maps them genome-wide to identify origin positions
Whole genome sequencing of a stationary-phase population
questions.explanation: Several genome-wide approaches can map replication origins, and short nascent strand (SNS) sequencing is one of the most direct. The principle: newly fired origins produce short nascent strands (0.5-2 kb) that initiate at the origin. By isolating size-fractionated newly synthesized DNA from S-phase cells (using lambda exonuclease to degrade non-origin DNA, as nascent strands are protected by their RNA primer), sequencing these fragments, and mapping them to the genome, origin positions can be identified at high resolution. Alternative approaches include: (1) Orc/MCM ChIP-seq—maps where ORC and MCM helicases bind (licensed origins); (2) Repli-seq—uses BrdU incorporation and cell sorting to map replication timing; (3) OK-seq—identifies Okazaki fragment polarity to infer fork directionality and origin positions; (4) Ini-seq—synchronizes cells and labels the earliest replicated DNA. Each approach has distinct strengths. SNS-seq provides direct positional information about active origins. In human cells, approximately 30,000-50,000 origins fire per S phase, though many more are licensed as dormant origins that serve as backup.

questions.question: The structure of nucleotides includes three components: a nitrogenous base, a pentose sugar, and one or more phosphate groups. In DNA, the bond connecting adjacent nucleotides in the same strand is:
options: A phosphodiester bond between the 3'-OH of one nucleotide's deoxyribose and the 5'-phosphate of the next nucleotide, creating a sugar-phosphate backbone
A hydrogen bond between the bases of adjacent nucleotides
An ionic bond between the phosphate groups of adjacent nucleotides
A peptide bond similar to those in proteins
questions.explanation: The backbone of each DNA strand consists of alternating deoxyribose sugars and phosphate groups connected by phosphodiester bonds. Specifically, the phosphate group forms two ester bonds: one to the 3'-carbon of one deoxyribose and another to the 5'-carbon of the next deoxyribose. This 3'-5' phosphodiester linkage creates the directionality of the DNA strand—one end has a free 5'-phosphate (5' end) and the other has a free 3'-hydroxyl (3' end). The sugar-phosphate backbone is on the outside of the double helix, while the bases project inward, perpendicular to the helical axis, where they form hydrogen bonds with complementary bases on the opposite strand. Phosphodiester bonds are covalent bonds, making the backbone extremely strong and resistant to mechanical stress. The anionic phosphate groups (negatively charged at physiological pH) make DNA a polyanion, which is important for interactions with positively charged histones and other DNA-binding proteins. DNA polymerase catalyzes the formation of new phosphodiester bonds during replication by a nucleophilic attack of the 3'-OH on the alpha-phosphate of the incoming dNTP.

questions.question: A double-stranded DNA molecule has 30% adenine. What is the percentage of guanine in this molecule?
options: 25%, assuming equal distribution of all bases
20%, because if A=30% then T=30% (by Chargaff's rule), leaving 40% for G+C equally split
30%, equal to adenine
10%, because purines and pyrimidines are not equally distributed
questions.explanation: This is a direct application of Chargaff's rules for double-stranded DNA. Rule 1: A=T (adenine equals thymine due to complementary base pairing). Rule 2: G=C (guanine equals cytosine). Since A=30%, then T=30% (by Chargaff's first rule). The total of A+T = 30%+30% = 60%. Since the four bases must account for 100% of the total, G+C = 100%-60% = 40%. By Chargaff's second rule, G=C, so each = 40%/2 = 20%. Therefore, guanine = 20%. This type of calculation is fundamental to understanding DNA composition. The GC content of this DNA is 40%, which would predict a relatively moderate melting temperature. It's important to note that these rules apply only to double-stranded DNA; in single-stranded DNA, A does not necessarily equal T. The rules arise from the structural requirement of Watson-Crick base pairing in the double helix, where each A on one strand pairs with a T on the complementary strand.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about DNA polymerase activities:

S1: All DNA polymerases require a primer with a free 3'-OH group to initiate synthesis
S2: E. coli DNA Pol I has both 5'-to-3' and 3'-to-5' exonuclease activities in addition to polymerase activity
S3: Eukaryotic DNA Pol alpha lacks 3'-to-5' exonuclease (proofreading) activity
S4: DNA polymerases add nucleotides to the 5' end of the growing chain
options: S1, S2, and S3 are correct; S4 is incorrect
Only S1 is correct; S2, S3, and S4 are incorrect
Only S1 and S2 are correct; S3 and S4 are incorrect
All four statements are correct
questions.explanation: S1 is CORRECT: All known DNA polymerases require a pre-existing primer with a free 3'-hydroxyl group. They cannot initiate DNA synthesis de novo. This is why primase (which can initiate synthesis de novo) is essential for providing RNA primers. S2 is CORRECT: E. coli DNA Pol I is unique in having three enzymatic activities: (1) 5'-to-3' polymerase activity, (2) 3'-to-5' exonuclease activity (proofreading), and (3) 5'-to-3' exonuclease activity (used for nick translation during primer removal). The Klenow fragment (large fragment of Pol I after protease cleavage) retains activities 1 and 2 but lacks activity 3. S3 is CORRECT: Eukaryotic DNA Pol alpha (associated with primase) lacks 3'-to-5' exonuclease activity, making it relatively error-prone. This is acceptable because the short DNA segment it synthesizes is later replaced during Okazaki fragment processing. S4 is INCORRECT: DNA polymerases add nucleotides to the 3' end (not the 5' end) of the growing chain. Synthesis proceeds in the 5'-to-3' direction, meaning the 3'-OH of the last nucleotide attacks the 5'-alpha-phosphate of the incoming dNTP.

questions.question: The concept of the replicon was first proposed by Jacob, Brenner, and Cuzin in 1963. A replicon is defined as:
options: A unit of DNA that is replicated from a single origin of replication, including the origin and the DNA replicated from it
A segment of DNA that is passed from parent to offspring unchanged
Any DNA molecule that can be transcribed into RNA
A protein complex that carries out DNA replication
questions.explanation: The replicon model proposed by Francois Jacob, Sydney Brenner, and Francois Cuzin defined the basic unit of DNA replication. A replicon consists of an origin of replication (cis-acting DNA element where replication initiates) and the DNA replicated from that origin. The model also proposed that a specific initiator protein (trans-acting factor) recognizes and acts at the origin to initiate replication. In E. coli, the entire circular chromosome is a single replicon: one origin (oriC) and one initiator protein (DnaA). In contrast, eukaryotic chromosomes contain multiple replicons—each human chromosome may contain hundreds of replicons, with origins spaced approximately every 30-300 kb. Some replicons fire early in S phase, others late, and some are dormant (licensed but only fire if needed). Plasmids and some bacteriophages are also replicons with their own origins and replication control systems. The replicon concept unified the understanding of DNA replication control across diverse systems and remains fundamental to molecular biology.

questions.question: To test whether a newly discovered DNA polymerase has proofreading activity, a researcher needs to design an assay. Which approach would be most direct?
options: Incubate the purified polymerase with a primer-template containing a 3' terminal mismatch, and assay for removal of the mismatched nucleotide using labeled substrates and gel electrophoresis
Test whether the polymerase can synthesize DNA without a primer
Measure the speed of DNA synthesis on an undamaged template
Observe the polymerase structure under electron microscopy
questions.explanation: Proofreading activity (3'-to-5' exonuclease activity) can be directly assayed by providing the polymerase with a substrate designed to trigger the exonuclease. The most direct approach: (1) Prepare a primer-template where the 3' terminal nucleotide of the primer is mismatched with the template (e.g., G opposite A). (2) Label the primer (e.g., with 32P at the 5' end or with a fluorescent tag). (3) Incubate the labeled primer-template with the purified polymerase in the absence of dNTPs (so the polymerase cannot extend, only excise). (4) Analyze the products by denaturing gel electrophoresis or HPLC. If the polymerase has 3'-to-5' exonuclease activity, the mismatched 3' nucleotide will be removed, producing a primer shortened by one nucleotide. Controls include: (a) matched primer-template (less exonuclease activity expected, since proofreading preferentially acts on mismatches), (b) heat-inactivated enzyme, and (c) known polymerase with and without proofreading activity (e.g., Pol I vs. Klenow exo-minus). The ratio of exonuclease activity on mismatched vs. matched substrates indicates proofreading specificity.

questions.question: Dideoxynucleotides (ddNTPs) are used in Sanger DNA sequencing. Why do ddNTPs terminate DNA chain elongation?
options: ddNTPs are too large to fit in the polymerase active site after incorporation
ddNTPs cause the DNA helix to denature at the incorporation site
ddNTPs lack the 3'-OH group on the deoxyribose sugar, so after incorporation, there is no hydroxyl available for the next phosphodiester bond formation
ddNTPs are recognized as errors and trigger proofreading excision
questions.explanation: Dideoxynucleotides (2',3'-dideoxynucleotides, ddNTPs) differ from normal deoxynucleotides (dNTPs) by lacking the 3'-hydroxyl group on the sugar—they have a hydrogen atom at the 3' position instead. During DNA synthesis, the phosphodiester bond between adjacent nucleotides is formed by a nucleophilic attack of the 3'-OH of the last nucleotide in the chain on the alpha-phosphate of the incoming nucleotide triphosphate. When a ddNTP is incorporated, the missing 3'-OH means there is no nucleophile available to attack the next incoming nucleotide, so chain elongation terminates at that position. This was exploited by Frederick Sanger (Nobel Prize, 1980) for DNA sequencing: by including a small proportion of one type of ddNTP (along with normal dNTPs) in a polymerase reaction, chain termination occurs randomly at every position where that particular base is incorporated, generating a ladder of fragments. Modern Sanger sequencing uses four different fluorescently labeled ddNTPs in a single reaction, with capillary electrophoresis separating fragments by size.

questions.question: Semiconservative replication has important implications for the distribution of epigenetic marks during cell division. After replication of a region with methylated CpG dinucleotides, the daughter duplexes are:
options: Fully methylated on both strands because methylation is copied simultaneously with DNA
Hemimethylated, with methylation on the parental strand but not the newly synthesized strand, requiring maintenance methyltransferase DNMT1 to restore full methylation
Completely unmethylated because replication removes all epigenetic marks
Randomly methylated with no relationship to the parental pattern
questions.explanation: DNA methylation at CpG dinucleotides is a critical epigenetic mark in mammals that must be faithfully transmitted through cell division. After semiconservative replication, each daughter duplex retains one parental strand (with its original methylation pattern) and one newly synthesized strand (which is unmethylated, as DNA polymerase incorporates unmodified cytosine). This creates hemimethylated DNA—methylated on one strand (parental) and unmethylated on the other (daughter). The maintenance methyltransferase DNMT1 (DNA methyltransferase 1) specifically recognizes hemimethylated CpG sites and adds methyl groups to the corresponding cytosines on the unmethylated daughter strand, restoring full methylation. DNMT1 is recruited to replication forks through its interaction with PCNA and UHRF1 (ubiquitin-like containing PHD and RING finger domains 1), which specifically binds hemimethylated DNA. This mechanism ensures that DNA methylation patterns are faithfully copied from parent to daughter cells. Failure of maintenance methylation can lead to gene activation, genomic instability, and disease.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the structure of DNA:

S1: The two strands of DNA run antiparallel, with one strand oriented 5'-to-3' and the other 3'-to-5'
S2: The major groove is wider and contains more chemical information than the minor groove, making it the preferred binding site for most transcription factors
S3: The bases are stacked with a spacing of 0.34 nm and there are 10 base pairs per turn in B-DNA
S4: DNA is a left-handed helix under all conditions
options: Only S2 is correct; S1, S3, and S4 are incorrect
Only S1 and S3 are correct; S2 and S4 are incorrect
S1, S2, and S3 are correct; S4 is incorrect
All four statements are correct
questions.explanation: S1 is CORRECT: The antiparallel orientation of DNA strands is a fundamental structural feature. One strand runs in the 5'-to-3' direction while the complementary strand runs 3'-to-5'. This antiparallel arrangement is dictated by the geometry of Watson-Crick base pairing and is essential for the function of DNA polymerases and other enzymes that track along DNA. S2 is CORRECT: The major groove (approximately 22 angstroms wide) is wider than the minor groove (approximately 12 angstroms) in B-DNA. More importantly, the pattern of hydrogen bond donors and acceptors in the major groove is unique for each of the four base pairs (AT, TA, GC, CG), allowing proteins to 'read' the DNA sequence without unwinding the helix. The minor groove has less distinguishing information. This is why most sequence-specific DNA-binding proteins (transcription factors, restriction enzymes) interact primarily through the major groove. S3 is CORRECT: In B-DNA, base pairs are stacked 0.34 nm apart with 10 bp per complete turn, giving a pitch of 3.4 nm. S4 is INCORRECT: B-DNA (the predominant physiological form) is a right-handed helix. Only Z-DNA is left-handed.

questions.question: A researcher isolates a temperature-sensitive E. coli mutant that grows normally at 30°C but stops DNA replication immediately when shifted to 42°C. Existing DNA forks complete replication, but no new rounds of replication initiate. When returned to 30°C, replication resumes. Which gene is most likely mutated?
options: lig, encoding DNA ligase
dnaA, encoding the initiator protein that binds oriC to start new rounds of replication, since the defect specifically affects initiation but not elongation
dnaE, encoding the alpha subunit (polymerase) of DNA Pol III
dnaB, encoding the replicative helicase
questions.explanation: The phenotype described is a classic initiation-defective mutation. The key observations are: (1) at the restrictive temperature (42°C), no NEW rounds of replication initiate, but (2) existing replication forks complete their rounds normally, and (3) the defect is reversible when returned to permissive temperature. This pattern specifically implicates the initiation step. DnaA protein binds to oriC and is required exclusively for initiation—it has no role in elongation. A temperature-sensitive dnaA mutation would produce a protein that functions at 30°C but misfolds or loses DNA-binding activity at 42°C. At 42°C, existing forks (which no longer need DnaA) continue to completion, but new initiations cannot occur. If dnaE (polymerase) or dnaB (helicase) were mutated, existing forks would also stall or stop because these enzymes are required for ongoing elongation. If lig (ligase) were mutated, Okazaki fragments would accumulate unjoined. The 'immediate stop of initiation with continuation of elongation' phenotype is diagnostic for dnaA mutations.

questions.question: Topoisomerase I and topoisomerase II differ in their mechanism of action. Which statement correctly distinguishes them?
options: Topoisomerase I makes a single-strand break and does not require ATP, while topoisomerase II makes a double-strand break and requires ATP hydrolysis
Both enzymes make double-strand breaks but differ in their cofactor requirements
Topoisomerase I is found only in prokaryotes while topoisomerase II is exclusive to eukaryotes
Topoisomerase I changes DNA supercoiling while topoisomerase II does not
questions.explanation: Type I and type II topoisomerases resolve topological problems in DNA through fundamentally different mechanisms. Type I topoisomerases (TopI) make a transient single-strand break (nick) in one strand, pass the other strand through the break (or rotate around the intact strand), and reseal the nick. This changes the linking number by +1 or -1 per cycle. TopI does not require ATP—the energy of the phosphodiester bond is conserved through a covalent enzyme-DNA intermediate (tyrosine-phosphodiester bond). Type II topoisomerases (TopII, including bacterial gyrase) make a transient double-strand break in one DNA segment (G-segment) and pass another DNA segment (T-segment) through the break, then reseal both strands. This changes the linking number by +2 or -2 per cycle. TopII requires ATP hydrolysis for the strand passage step. Both types exist in prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Bacterial gyrase is unique among type II topoisomerases in being able to introduce negative supercoils; eukaryotic TopoII only relaxes supercoils. Both types are drug targets: camptothecin targets TopI, and etoposide targets TopII.

questions.question: The alternative lengthening of telomeres (ALT) pathway maintains telomere length in approximately 10-15% of cancers without telomerase. ALT primarily operates through:
options: Telomere-specific base excision repair that adds nucleotides one at a time
Homologous recombination between telomeric sequences, using one telomere as a template to extend another, generating heterogeneous telomere lengths and ALT-associated PML bodies
De novo synthesis of telomeric repeats by a specialized DNA polymerase
Reverse transcription using retrotransposon-encoded enzymes
questions.explanation: The ALT pathway is a telomerase-independent mechanism for maintaining telomere length that operates in approximately 10-15% of human cancers (particularly sarcomas, glioblastomas, and some carcinomas). ALT utilizes homologous recombination (HR) between telomeric sequences on different chromosomes (or within the same telomere). Several recombination-based mechanisms contribute: (1) intertelomeric HR, where one telomere invades and copies telomeric DNA from another chromosome; (2) intratelomeric HR (T-loop resolution), where the T-loop structure is resolved by HR, generating extrachromosomal telomeric circles (C-circles and T-circles); (3) break-induced replication (BIR) at telomeres. Hallmarks of ALT cells include: heterogeneous telomere lengths (some very long, some very short), the presence of ALT-associated PML (promyelocytic leukemia) bodies (APBs) where telomeric DNA co-localizes with recombination proteins, abundant extrachromosomal telomeric DNA (particularly C-circles), and elevated telomeric sister chromatid exchange. ALT is promoted by loss of ATRX or DAXX chromatin remodeling factors.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the evidence that DNA is the genetic material:

S1: Griffith showed that a transforming principle could change R-strain pneumococci into S-strain
S2: Avery, MacLeod, and McCarty identified the transforming principle as DNA through enzyme degradation experiments
S3: Hershey and Chase used radioactive isotopes to show that phage DNA, not protein, enters the bacterial cell during infection
S4: Watson and Crick's model showed that DNA structure is incompatible with carrying genetic information
options: S1, S2, and S3 are correct; S4 is incorrect
All four statements are correct
Only S1 is correct; S2, S3, and S4 are incorrect
Only S1 and S3 are correct; S2 and S4 are incorrect
questions.explanation: S1 is CORRECT: Frederick Griffith's 1928 experiment with Streptococcus pneumoniae demonstrated that a heat-stable 'transforming principle' from dead virulent S-strain bacteria could convert live avirulent R-strain into virulent S-strain. While Griffith did not identify the chemical nature of this principle, the experiment established that genetic information could be transferred between cells. S2 is CORRECT: In 1944, Avery, MacLeod, and McCarty purified the transforming principle and demonstrated it was DNA by showing that DNase destroyed transforming activity while RNase and protease did not. Chemical analysis confirmed DNA properties. S3 is CORRECT: The Hershey-Chase experiment (1952) used 32P-labeled DNA and 35S-labeled protein in bacteriophage T2 to demonstrate that DNA (not protein) entered bacterial cells during phage infection and directed new phage production. S4 is INCORRECT: Watson and Crick's model (1953) showed that DNA structure IS compatible with genetic information storage and transmission. Their complementary base pairing model immediately suggested a replication mechanism, and the specific base sequence could encode genetic information.

questions.question: A researcher wants to measure the error rate of a purified DNA polymerase in vitro. Which experimental design would provide the most accurate measurement?
options: Use a defined template with a reporter gene (like lacZ), allow the polymerase to replicate it, transform the products into bacteria, and score the frequency of mutant (white) colonies on X-gal indicator plates
Measure the speed of nucleotide incorporation by the polymerase
Observe the polymerase with cryo-electron microscopy during replication
Compare the molecular weight of input and output DNA molecules
questions.explanation: The most robust method for measuring DNA polymerase error rate in vitro is a forward mutation assay using a reporter gene system. The approach: (1) Prepare a single-stranded circular DNA template containing a reporter gene like lacZ-alpha (as in the M13mp2 lacZ reversion assay developed by Thomas Kunkel). (2) Allow the purified polymerase to fill in the gap (synthesize the complementary strand) in vitro under controlled conditions. (3) Transform the double-stranded products into a lacZ-alpha-deleted E. coli strain. (4) Plate on X-gal/IPTG indicator plates. Blue colonies contain wild-type lacZ (no errors in the target region), while white/light blue colonies contain mutations that inactivate the reporter. (5) Sequence the mutant clones to determine the types of errors (transitions, transversions, frameshifts). The error rate = number of mutations / (number of detectable sites × number of nucleotides copied). This assay can measure error rates from ~10^-3 to ~10^-6 per nucleotide, depending on the polymerase. It has been used extensively to characterize the fidelity of various DNA polymerases.

questions.question: Hydroxyurea is a drug used in cancer treatment and for sickle cell disease. In the context of DNA replication, hydroxyurea functions by:
options: Activating DNA degradation enzymes that destroy newly synthesized DNA
Inhibiting DNA ligase and preventing Okazaki fragment joining
Directly binding to DNA and preventing strand separation
Inhibiting ribonucleotide reductase, depleting the pool of deoxyribonucleotides needed for DNA synthesis, causing replication fork stalling
questions.explanation: Hydroxyurea (HU) inhibits ribonucleotide reductase (RNR), the enzyme that converts ribonucleotides to deoxyribonucleotides. RNR catalyzes the reduction of the 2'-OH of ribonucleoside diphosphates to produce deoxyribonucleoside diphosphates (e.g., ADP to dADP, GDP to dGDP). By inhibiting RNR, hydroxyurea depletes the cellular pool of dNTPs required for DNA synthesis. Without sufficient dNTPs, DNA polymerases stall at replication forks, triggering the intra-S phase checkpoint. In cancer treatment, this kills rapidly dividing cells that have high dNTP demand. In sickle cell disease, hydroxyurea works differently: by causing replicative stress, it induces fetal hemoglobin (HbF) expression through stress erythropoiesis, and HbF inhibits HbS polymerization. Hydroxyurea specifically targets the free radical mechanism of RNR (the tyrosyl radical on the R2 subunit is quenched by HU). In research, HU is commonly used to synchronize cells at early S phase or to study replication fork stalling and restart mechanisms.

questions.question: The replication fork speed in eukaryotes (~50 bp/s) is much slower than in prokaryotes (~1000 bp/s). A major reason for this difference is:
options: Eukaryotic DNA polymerases have lower catalytic rates than prokaryotic polymerases
Eukaryotic DNA is packaged into nucleosomes that must be disassembled ahead of the fork and reassembled behind it, creating a physical barrier that slows fork progression
Eukaryotic cells have fewer dNTP pools available for replication
The larger genome of eukaryotes requires slower replication to avoid errors
questions.explanation: The major impediment to eukaryotic replication fork progression is chromatin structure. Eukaryotic DNA is wrapped around histone octamers forming nucleosomes spaced every ~200 bp. The replication machinery must: (1) disassemble nucleosomes ahead of the advancing fork, requiring chromatin remodeling complexes (like FACT, INO80, and ISWI family members); (2) unwind the DNA from histones; (3) replicate through the now-naked DNA; (4) rapidly reassemble nucleosomes on both daughter duplexes behind the fork, distributing parental histones and depositing new ones. This nucleosome barrier significantly reduces the rate of fork progression compared to naked DNA. In vitro, when eukaryotic replication is reconstituted on naked DNA templates, fork rates can approach prokaryotic speeds. Additionally, the need to coordinate chromatin assembly with DNA synthesis adds regulatory checkpoints. While intrinsic differences in polymerase catalytic rates and the more complex replisome architecture also contribute, the chromatin barrier is the dominant factor explaining the ~20-fold reduction in fork speed.

questions.question: Depurination is a spontaneous chemical reaction that removes purine bases (A or G) from DNA, creating an apurinic (AP) site. Approximately how many depurination events occur per human cell per day?
options: Approximately 5,000-10,000 events, making it one of the most frequent types of endogenous DNA damage requiring constant repair by the BER pathway
Millions of events, affecting every nucleotide in the genome simultaneously
Fewer than 10 events per year, making it a rare occurrence
Exactly 1 event per cell division, always at the same position
questions.explanation: Depurination is one of the most common spontaneous DNA lesions in living cells. The N-glycosidic bond between purine bases (adenine and guanine) and the deoxyribose sugar is intrinsically labile and undergoes spontaneous hydrolysis at physiological pH and temperature. Estimates indicate approximately 5,000-10,000 purines are lost per human cell per day (some estimates suggest up to 18,000). If unrepaired, AP sites are highly mutagenic because DNA polymerase may insert an incorrect base opposite the missing purine during replication, or the AP site may block replication entirely. AP sites are repaired primarily by the base excision repair (BER) pathway: AP endonuclease (APE1) cleaves the phosphodiester backbone 5' to the AP site, DNA polymerase beta fills the gap, and DNA ligase III seals the nick. The frequency of depurination underscores the importance of constant DNA repair: without BER, the accumulation of AP sites would rapidly lead to genome instability, mutations, and cell death. Depyrimidination also occurs but at approximately 5% the rate of depurination because the glycosidic bond to pyrimidines is more stable.

questions.question: The licensing-firing model ensures that each origin of replication fires only once per cell cycle. What would happen if the licensing control were bypassed, allowing origins to fire multiple times?
options: Nothing would happen because origins naturally fire only once regardless of regulation
The cell would simply complete replication faster with no adverse effects
The cell would enter mitosis immediately without completing S phase
Re-replication would occur, leading to gene amplification, genome instability, and activation of the DNA damage response, potentially causing cell death or cancer progression
questions.explanation: The prevention of re-replication (firing the same origin more than once per cell cycle) is essential for maintaining genome integrity. If the licensing control is bypassed (experimentally achieved by overexpressing Cdc6 and Cdt1 while inhibiting geminin, or by deregulating CDK activity), the consequences include: (1) Re-replication of genomic segments, producing regions with >2 copies of DNA. This creates 'onion-skin' replication bubbles visible by electron microscopy. (2) Collisions between convergent replication forks from re-fired origins, generating DNA double-strand breaks. (3) Activation of the DNA damage response (ATR/ATM kinases, checkpoint activation), leading to cell cycle arrest, senescence, or apoptosis. (4) If the cell survives, gene amplification (extra copies of genes) and genomic instability can drive cancer progression. In fact, overexpression of licensing factors (Cdc6, Cdt1) and loss of licensing inhibitors (geminin) have been observed in various cancers. The cell invests enormous regulatory effort in preventing re-replication through multiple redundant mechanisms targeting Cdc6, Cdt1, ORC, and MCM.

questions.question: A student performs a virtual Meselson-Stahl experiment starting with 100 molecules of 15N-labeled DNA. After 4 generations of growth in 14N medium, how many molecules will be at intermediate density and how many at light density?
options: 2 intermediate and 1,598 light (2^4 × 100 = 1600 total; 200 intermediate strands means 100 intermediate molecules; wait — actually 200 original 15N strands produce 200 hybrid molecules...no. The answer is 200 intermediate and 1,400 light
100 heavy and 1,500 light
All 1,600 molecules at intermediate density
800 intermediate and 800 light
questions.explanation: Starting with 100 fully 15N-labeled DNA molecules (200 heavy strands total). After each generation of semiconservative replication in 14N medium, the number of molecules doubles. After 4 generations: 100 × 2^4 = 1,600 total molecules. The key insight is that each of the original 200 heavy (15N) strands is conserved through all generations, always paired with a new 14N strand, producing an intermediate-density molecule. So there will always be exactly 200 intermediate-density molecules (one for each original 15N strand). The remaining molecules are light (both strands 14N): 1,600 - 200 = 1,400 light molecules. Therefore: 200 intermediate + 1,400 light = 1,600 total. As n increases, the fraction of intermediate molecules approaches zero (200/total = 200/100×2^n), but the absolute number remains constant at 200 (equal to the number of original strands). This elegantly demonstrates that individual parental strands are permanently conserved in semiconservative replication.

questions.question: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic DNA polymerases share fundamental catalytic properties but differ in several aspects. Which feature is shared by ALL DNA polymerases across all domains of life?
options: They all require a template strand, a primer with a free 3'-OH, and dNTP substrates, and they all synthesize DNA in the 5'-to-3' direction
They all use the same sliding clamp protein for processivity
They all function as monomeric enzymes with a single polypeptide
They all have 3'-to-5' exonuclease proofreading activity
questions.explanation: Despite enormous diversity in size, subunit composition, and specific functions, ALL DNA polymerases share four fundamental requirements: (1) A template strand that specifies the sequence of the new strand through Watson-Crick base pairing; (2) A primer with a free 3'-hydroxyl group, which provides the nucleophile for the phosphodiester bond-forming reaction; (3) Deoxynucleoside triphosphate (dNTP) substrates; (4) Synthesis in the 5'-to-3' direction by adding nucleotides to the 3' end of the growing chain. These universal features reflect the ancient origin and fundamental chemical mechanism of DNA polymerase: the 3'-OH of the primer performs a nucleophilic attack on the alpha-phosphate of the incoming dNTP, releasing pyrophosphate. Not all polymerases have proofreading activity (e.g., Pol alpha, Pol beta, and Y-family TLS polymerases lack it). Sliding clamps are functionally conserved but structurally different (bacterial beta-clamp is a homodimer; eukaryotic PCNA is a homotrimer). Many polymerases are multisubunit complexes, not monomers.

questions.question: Fragile sites in human chromosomes are specific loci that show gaps or breaks under replication stress (e.g., low-dose aphidicolin treatment). Common fragile sites are associated with:
options: Centromeric regions where kinetochore attachment causes mechanical stress
Telomeric regions exclusively
Very large genes (>500 kb) in late-replicating regions where replication fork stalling and incomplete replication lead to chromosome breakage during mitosis
Regions of extremely high GC content that cannot be unwound
questions.explanation: Common fragile sites (CFSs) are chromosomal regions that are particularly prone to forming gaps, breaks, and rearrangements under conditions of replication stress. Key characteristics of CFSs include: (1) They often contain very large genes (many >1 Mb), such as FHIT at FRA3B (1.5 Mb) and WWOX at FRA16D (1.1 Mb). These large genes take many hours to replicate, and any replication fork stalling creates particularly long unreplicated gaps. (2) They replicate late in S phase, leaving less time for completion before mitosis. (3) They are origin-poor, meaning few backup (dormant) origins can be activated if forks stall. (4) They may contain AT-rich sequences that form secondary structures impeding fork progression. Under replication stress (reduced dNTP pools, polymerase inhibition), forks stall preferentially at these sites. If the cell enters mitosis with unreplicated DNA at these loci, the resulting mechanical tension causes chromosome breakage. CFSs are hotspots for deletions and rearrangements in cancer—for example, FHIT is deleted in many lung, breast, and kidney cancers.

questions.question: The Fanconi anemia (FA) pathway is a DNA repair mechanism that is specifically activated by interstrand crosslinks (ICLs). How do ICLs differ from other types of DNA damage?
options: ICLs only affect one strand and can be repaired by simple excision
ICLs are the least harmful type of DNA damage because they stabilize the helix
ICLs covalently link both strands of the double helix, blocking strand separation and preventing both replication fork progression and transcription
ICLs occur only in mitochondrial DNA, not nuclear DNA
questions.explanation: Interstrand crosslinks (ICLs) are among the most toxic DNA lesions because they covalently connect the two strands of the double helix, preventing strand separation. This blocks both DNA replication (the helicase cannot unwind the crosslinked strands) and transcription (RNA polymerase cannot pass through). ICLs are caused by chemotherapeutic agents (cisplatin, mitomycin C, nitrogen mustards) and endogenous aldehydes (formaldehyde, acetaldehyde from ethanol metabolism, malondialdehyde from lipid peroxidation). Repair of ICLs is uniquely complex, requiring coordination of multiple repair pathways: (1) The FA pathway recognizes the stalled replication fork at the ICL and monoubiquitinates FANCD2-FANCI. (2) Nucleases (including XPF-ERCC1) make incisions flanking the crosslink on one strand (unhooking). (3) Translesion synthesis bypasses the unhooked crosslink remnant. (4) NER removes the crosslink remnant from the other strand. (5) Homologous recombination repairs the resulting double-strand break. Mutations in any of the 22+ FA genes cause Fanconi anemia, characterized by bone marrow failure, developmental abnormalities, and cancer predisposition.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the fidelity of DNA replication:

S1: Base selection by the polymerase active site contributes an error rate of approximately 1 in 10^5
S2: Proofreading by the 3'-to-5' exonuclease reduces the error rate by approximately 100-fold to 1 in 10^7
S3: Mismatch repair further reduces the error rate by approximately 100-1000-fold to 1 in 10^9-10^10
S4: The overall error rate of DNA replication is higher than the error rate of RNA transcription
options: S1, S2, and S3 are correct; S4 is incorrect
Only S1 and S3 are correct; S2 and S4 are incorrect
All four statements are correct
Only S1 is correct; S2, S3, and S4 are incorrect
questions.explanation: S1 is CORRECT: The initial base selection by the polymerase active site provides an error rate of approximately 10^-5 (1 error per 100,000 nucleotides). This selectivity arises from the geometric constraints of the active site, which preferentially accommodate correct Watson-Crick base pairs. The free energy difference between correct and incorrect base pairs drives this selection. S2 is CORRECT: The 3'-to-5' exonuclease (proofreading) activity provides a second checkpoint. When a mismatch is incorporated, the distorted geometry of the primer terminus shifts the 3' end from the polymerase to the exonuclease active site, where the mismatched nucleotide is removed. This improves fidelity approximately 100-fold to ~10^-7. S3 is CORRECT: Post-replicative mismatch repair (MutS-MutL-MutH in E. coli; MSH-MLH/PMS in eukaryotes) provides the final correction, reducing the error rate another 100-1000-fold to approximately 10^-9 to 10^-10. S4 is INCORRECT: DNA replication (~10^-9-10^-10 errors/bp) is much MORE accurate than RNA transcription (~10^-4-10^-5 errors/nt). RNA polymerase lacks proofreading and has no equivalent of mismatch repair. This is tolerable because RNA molecules are transient.

questions.question: A researcher treats E. coli cells with UV light and then measures the survival rate over time under two conditions: cells kept in the dark and cells exposed to visible light after UV treatment. She observes significantly higher survival in the light-exposed cells. What mechanism explains this difference?
options: Dark conditions cause additional DNA damage beyond UV effects
Visible light stimulates cell division, diluting the damaged DNA
Light exposure activates the SOS response more efficiently
Photoreactivation by photolyase, which uses visible light energy to directly reverse UV-induced pyrimidine dimers, providing a rapid repair mechanism that increases survival
questions.explanation: This classic experiment demonstrates photoreactivation, a direct reversal repair mechanism. UV radiation causes formation of cyclobutane pyrimidine dimers (CPDs) and 6-4 photoproducts in DNA. Photolyase is an enzyme that binds to pyrimidine dimers and uses energy from visible light (blue/UV-A wavelengths, 300-500 nm) to catalyze the splitting of the cyclobutane ring, restoring the two pyrimidines to their original monomeric state. The enzyme contains two chromophore cofactors: FADH- (the catalytic cofactor that directly transfers an electron to break the dimer) and either MTHF (methenyltetrahydrofolate) or 8-HDF (8-hydroxy-5-deazaflavin) as a light-harvesting antenna. In the dark, photolyase can still bind to dimers but cannot catalyze repair without light energy, so cells must rely solely on NER (which is slower). Under visible light, photoreactivation rapidly removes dimers, dramatically increasing survival. Interestingly, placental mammals have lost photolyase during evolution and rely entirely on NER for pyrimidine dimer repair. The homologous cryptochrome proteins in mammals function as circadian rhythm photoreceptors instead.

questions.question: G-quadruplex (G4) structures are non-canonical DNA structures that can form in G-rich sequences. These structures are particularly enriched at:
options: Exclusively in mitochondrial DNA
Random positions throughout the genome with no functional significance
Only at centromeres where they facilitate kinetochore attachment
Telomeres and gene promoter regions, where they may regulate telomere maintenance and gene expression
questions.explanation: G-quadruplexes (G4 structures) form when four guanine bases associate through Hoogsteen hydrogen bonding to create a planar G-quartet, and multiple G-quartets stack to form a stable four-stranded structure. G4-forming sequences (consensus: G3+N1-7G3+N1-7G3+N1-7G3+) are particularly enriched at two genomic locations: (1) Telomeres, where the G-rich TTAGGG repeat strand readily forms G4 structures. These may regulate telomerase access and play roles in telomere protection. (2) Gene promoters, where >40% of human gene promoters contain potential G4-forming sequences. G4 structures in promoters can regulate transcription, typically acting as repressive elements when formed in the template strand (blocking RNA polymerase) or regulatory elements when in the non-template strand. The MYC oncogene promoter contains a well-characterized G4 that represses transcription. G4 structures also form at replication origins and within the first intron of many genes. Specialized helicases (like BLM, WRN, FANCJ, RTEL1) resolve G4 structures to allow replication fork progression. G4-stabilizing compounds are being developed as anticancer agents.

questions.question: The replisome in E. coli contains two copies of the DNA Pol III core connected by the tau subunit. This dimeric arrangement is important because:
options: It allows coordinated and simultaneous synthesis of both leading and lagging strands at the same replication fork, physically coupling the two polymerases
One copy proofreads while the other synthesizes
It doubles the speed of leading strand synthesis
The two copies alternate between active and inactive states
questions.explanation: The tau (encoded by dnaX) subunit of the E. coli replisome is a critical organizer that physically couples the leading and lagging strand polymerases. The tau dimer connects two Pol III core assemblies (each consisting of alpha-epsilon-theta subunits) into a single functional unit. This dimeric arrangement has several important consequences: (1) Both strands are synthesized simultaneously at the same rate, maintaining fork symmetry. (2) The physical connection ensures that leading and lagging strand synthesis are coordinated—if one strand is delayed, the coupled fork adjusts. (3) Tau also connects the polymerase to the DnaB helicase, creating a direct mechanical link between unwinding and synthesis. (4) The 'trombone' model of lagging strand synthesis requires that the lagging strand polymerase remain physically associated with the fork (through tau) even as it cycles between Okazaki fragments. Without the tau-mediated coupling, the lagging strand polymerase would dissociate completely after each Okazaki fragment, dramatically slowing replication. Recent studies suggest the replisome may actually contain three Pol III cores, with a third copy serving as a spare for rapid exchange during lagging strand recycling.

questions.question: Werner syndrome is a premature aging disorder caused by mutations in the WRN gene. The WRN protein has both helicase and exonuclease activities and is involved in:
options: Only transcription of ribosomal RNA genes
Protein translation at the ribosome
Multiple DNA repair pathways including BER, HR, NHEJ, and telomere maintenance, explaining the broad spectrum of accelerated aging phenotypes
Exclusively mitotic spindle formation during cell division
questions.explanation: Werner syndrome (WS) is an autosomal recessive progeroid syndrome characterized by premature aging features appearing in the teens and twenties: graying hair, cataracts, type 2 diabetes, osteoporosis, atherosclerosis, and increased cancer risk (particularly sarcomas). The WRN protein is a member of the RecQ helicase family with both 3'-to-5' helicase and 3'-to-5' exonuclease activities. WRN participates in multiple DNA metabolic processes: (1) Base excision repair: WRN interacts with DNA Pol beta and stimulates strand displacement synthesis. (2) Homologous recombination: WRN processes recombination intermediates and resolves aberrant structures. (3) NHEJ: WRN interacts with Ku70/80 and participates in end processing. (4) Telomere maintenance: WRN resolves G-quadruplex structures at telomeres and prevents telomere dysfunction. WS cells show accelerated telomere shortening, increased replicative senescence, and elevated chromosomal instability. The involvement of WRN in so many repair pathways explains why its loss produces such a broad spectrum of aging-associated phenotypes. Other RecQ helicase disorders include Bloom syndrome (BLM) and Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RECQL4).

questions.question: A researcher wants to determine whether a specific 500 bp sequence functions as an origin of replication in yeast. What is the classic experimental approach to test this?
options: Clone the sequence into a plasmid lacking a replication origin (ARS), transform yeast, and test whether the plasmid can replicate autonomously as measured by colony formation on selective media
Delete the sequence from the genome and observe whether cells can still divide
Measure the DNA content of cells by flow cytometry before and after adding the sequence
Sequence the 500 bp region and compare it to known origin consensus sequences
questions.explanation: The classic assay for origin function in yeast is the ARS (Autonomously Replicating Sequence) assay, developed by Struhl et al. and Stinchcomb et al. in 1979. The experimental approach: (1) Clone the candidate sequence into a plasmid that contains a selectable marker (e.g., URA3 or LEU2) but lacks a functional origin of replication. Without a replication origin, this plasmid cannot be maintained in yeast cells. (2) Transform yeast cells with this construct and plate on selective medium (e.g., lacking uracil for URA3 selection). (3) If the candidate sequence contains an ARS element (origin of replication), the plasmid will replicate autonomously in yeast cells, allowing colony formation on selective plates. (4) If the sequence lacks origin function, the plasmid cannot replicate, is rapidly lost during cell division, and no stable transformants appear (or very rare integrants only). This assay was instrumental in identifying ARS elements in S. cerevisiae, which contain the ARS consensus sequence (ACS): 5'-[A/T]TTTAT[A/G]TTT[A/T]-3'. Over 400 ARS elements have been identified in the yeast genome. More refined analyses use 2D gel electrophoresis to detect replication intermediates.

questions.question: The enzyme primase (DnaG in E. coli) differs from DNA polymerase in a critical way that explains why it is needed to start replication. This key difference is:
options: Primase has proofreading activity that is more accurate than any polymerase
Primase can work at higher temperatures than DNA polymerase
Primase synthesizes DNA faster than any DNA polymerase
Primase can initiate nucleic acid synthesis de novo without requiring a pre-existing primer, while all DNA polymerases require a primer with a free 3'-OH
questions.explanation: The fundamental distinction between primase and DNA polymerases is the ability to initiate synthesis de novo. All DNA polymerases have an absolute requirement for a pre-existing primer with a free 3'-hydroxyl group—they can only add nucleotides to an existing chain. They cannot begin a new chain from scratch. Primase (DnaG in E. coli) is an RNA polymerase that CAN initiate synthesis de novo, assembling a short RNA chain (~10-12 nucleotides in E. coli) on the DNA template without any primer. This RNA primer then provides the 3'-OH that DNA polymerase needs to begin DNA synthesis. The inability of DNA polymerases to start chains de novo is not a deficiency—it is actually thought to be a feature that ensures fidelity. Starting a new chain de novo is inherently error-prone (no template-checking of the first nucleotide), and using an RNA primer means these error-prone initiations occur in RNA that is later removed and replaced with accurately synthesized DNA. In eukaryotes, primase is tightly associated with DNA Pol alpha in the Pol alpha-primase complex.

questions.question: Bloom syndrome is caused by mutations in the BLM gene, which encodes a RecQ family DNA helicase. Cells from Bloom syndrome patients characteristically show:
options: Normal DNA replication with no detectable chromosomal abnormalities
Only defects in RNA transcription, not DNA replication
Complete absence of DNA replication
Elevated rates of sister chromatid exchanges (SCEs), indicating excessive recombination between sister chromatids during DNA repair
questions.explanation: Bloom syndrome (BS) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by growth retardation, sun sensitivity, immunodeficiency, and a dramatically increased risk of all types of cancer at an early age. The hallmark cytogenetic feature of BS cells is a 10-fold increase in sister chromatid exchanges (SCEs). BLM helicase normally functions to suppress inappropriate recombination: (1) It dissolves double Holliday junctions (together with topoisomerase IIIalpha, RMI1, and RMI2) through a mechanism called dissolution, which produces non-crossover products. Without BLM, Holliday junctions are resolved by structure-specific nucleases, producing crossover products (SCEs). (2) BLM disrupts RAD51-mediated D-loops during homologous recombination, preventing excessive or inappropriate recombination events. (3) BLM processes stalled replication forks, preventing their collapse into double-strand breaks that would trigger recombination. The elevated SCE rate is so characteristic that it is used as a diagnostic test for BS. The increased recombination leads to loss of heterozygosity (LOH), which can unmask recessive tumor suppressor mutations, explaining the cancer predisposition.

questions.question: A DNA molecule has the following sequence on one strand: 5'-ATGCCGTA-3'. What is the sequence of the complementary strand, written in the conventional 5'-to-3' direction?
options: 3'-TACGGCAT-5'
5'-ATGCCGTA-3'
5'-UACGGCAU-3'
5'-TACGGCAT-3'
questions.explanation: To determine the complementary strand, apply Watson-Crick base pairing rules (A pairs with T, G pairs with C) and the antiparallel orientation of DNA strands. The given strand is 5'-ATGCCGTA-3'. The complementary strand, written 3'-to-5', would be: 3'-TACGGCAT-5'. Convention dictates writing sequences in the 5'-to-3' direction, so we reverse this: 5'-TACGGCAT-3'. Step by step: A(5')→T, T→A, G→C, C→G, C→G, G→C, T→A, A(3')→T, giving 3'-TACGGCAT-5', which when written 5'-to-3' is 5'-TACGGCAT-3'. This is a fundamental skill in molecular biology—reading sequences in the correct orientation. Note that option D would be RNA (containing U instead of T) and is therefore incorrect for a DNA complementary strand. Option C is technically the complementary strand but written in the 3'-to-5' direction, which is non-standard. Always write sequences 5'-to-3' unless explicitly stated otherwise.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic DNA replication:

S1: Prokaryotes have a single origin of replication while eukaryotes have multiple origins per chromosome
S2: Eukaryotic Okazaki fragments (~100-200 nt) are shorter than prokaryotic ones (~1000-2000 nt)
S3: Both prokaryotes and eukaryotes use RNA primers to initiate DNA synthesis
S4: Eukaryotic DNA replication occurs only during S phase while prokaryotic replication can occur continuously
options: All four statements are correct
Only S1 is correct; S2, S3, and S4 are incorrect
Only S1 and S3 are correct; S2 and S4 are incorrect
S1, S2, and S3 are correct; S4 is incorrect
questions.explanation: All four statements are correct. S1: E. coli has a single origin (oriC) on its circular chromosome. Eukaryotic chromosomes have multiple origins—yeast has ~400 origins for 16 chromosomes, and human cells have ~30,000-50,000 active origins across 46 chromosomes. Multiple origins compensate for slower fork rates and larger genomes. S2: Eukaryotic Okazaki fragments are indeed shorter (~100-200 nt vs. ~1000-2000 nt in prokaryotes), likely related to nucleosome spacing and the frequency of primer synthesis. S3: Both use RNA primers synthesized by primase. In prokaryotes, DnaG primase works alone; in eukaryotes, primase is complexed with DNA Pol alpha. RNA primers serve the universal function of providing the 3'-OH that DNA polymerases cannot create de novo. S4: In eukaryotes, DNA replication is restricted to S phase by cell cycle regulatory mechanisms (licensing in G1, firing in S, prevention of re-replication in G2/M). In prokaryotes like E. coli, replication initiation is linked to cell mass and growth rate, and under rapid growth conditions, new rounds can initiate before the previous round is complete (overlapping replication cycles).

questions.question: The AT content of DNA at origins of replication tends to be higher than the genome average. This is advantageous for replication initiation because:
options: AT-rich regions bind more histones, facilitating origin recognition
Adenine absorbs more UV light, allowing the origin to be detected by light-sensing proteins
AT base pairs have two hydrogen bonds compared to three for GC pairs, requiring less energy to melt and facilitating initial strand separation by the initiator protein
Thymine residues are required as substrates for primase
questions.explanation: The enrichment of AT base pairs at replication origins is a conserved feature across many organisms and directly relates to the thermodynamics of strand separation. Initiator proteins (DnaA in E. coli, ORC in eukaryotes) must promote local DNA melting (strand separation) at origins to begin replication. AT base pairs are inherently easier to separate than GC base pairs for two reasons: (1) AT base pairs have only two hydrogen bonds compared to three for GC base pairs, requiring less energy input; (2) AT base pairs have weaker stacking interactions with neighboring base pairs. In E. coli, the oriC contains AT-rich 13-mer repeats that are the sites of initial melting by DnaA-ATP. Similarly, in S. cerevisiae, the essential T-rich element of the ARS consensus sequence is the site of initial unwinding. Even in human cells, origins tend to be associated with AT-rich regions. This physical property of AT-rich DNA—easier melting—is exploited by the replication initiation machinery across all domains of life. The same principle explains why AT-rich promoters (like TATA boxes) facilitate strand separation during transcription initiation.

questions.question: PARP inhibitors (like olaparib) are used to treat BRCA1/2-mutant cancers. The therapeutic principle behind this approach is called synthetic lethality. How does it work?
options: PARP inhibitors directly kill all dividing cells regardless of BRCA status
PARP inhibitors repair the BRCA mutation, restoring normal gene function
PARP inhibitors block single-strand break repair, causing DSBs during replication. Normal cells repair these DSBs via HR, but BRCA-mutant cancer cells cannot, leading to selective cancer cell death
PARP inhibitors prevent cancer cells from entering S phase
questions.explanation: Synthetic lethality occurs when loss of function of two genes individually is viable but simultaneous loss of both is lethal. PARP1 (poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase 1) plays a key role in single-strand break (SSB) repair and BER. When PARP is inhibited: (1) SSBs accumulate and are converted to double-strand breaks (DSBs) when replication forks encounter them (fork collapse). (2) In normal cells, these DSBs are efficiently repaired by homologous recombination (HR) using the intact BRCA1/BRCA2 pathway, so PARP inhibition alone is tolerable. (3) In BRCA1/2-mutant cancer cells, HR is defective, so the DSBs cannot be accurately repaired. The cells must rely on error-prone pathways like NHEJ, leading to massive genomic instability, chromosome aberrations, and cell death. This creates selective toxicity: PARP inhibitors kill BRCA-mutant cancer cells while sparing normal cells (which have at least one functional BRCA allele). Additionally, PARP trapping (the inhibitor traps PARP on DNA, creating a replication block) contributes to cytotoxicity. Olaparib (Lynparza) was the first PARP inhibitor approved for clinical use.

questions.question: A researcher examines DNA fiber spreads from cells pulse-labeled with IdU (iododeoxyuridine) followed by CldU (chlorodeoxyuridine), using antibodies that specifically detect each analog. She observes that most fibers show a pattern of red (IdU) followed by green (CldU) tracks of similar length. However, in cells treated with a DNA-damaging agent, the green (CldU) tracks become significantly shorter. What does this indicate?
options: The DNA-damaging agent causes replication fork slowing or stalling, reducing the distance traveled during the CldU labeling period compared to the IdU control period
The CldU analog is degraded by the damaging agent
The red antibody has higher affinity than the green antibody after DNA damage
The cells stopped dividing during the experiment
questions.explanation: DNA fiber analysis (also called DNA combing or molecular combing) is a powerful single-molecule technique for studying replication dynamics. The dual-labeling protocol works as follows: cells are first pulsed with IdU (detected by red-fluorescent antibodies), then with CldU (detected by green-fluorescent antibodies). Each replication fork incorporates the analogs sequentially, producing a fiber with a red segment followed by a green segment. The length of each colored segment is proportional to the distance traveled by the fork during that labeling period. If the green tracks become shorter after DNA damage treatment (while red tracks remain normal length), this indicates that forks are moving more slowly during the CldU pulse (when the damage is present). This fork slowing is a hallmark of the intra-S checkpoint activation: ATR/Chk1 signaling in response to DNA damage slows fork progression, reduces origin firing, and allows time for repair. Shortened green tracks can also indicate increased fork stalling or collapse. This assay provides direct, single-molecule measurement of replication fork dynamics and is widely used in cancer research and DNA repair studies.

questions.question: The Kornberg enzyme (DNA Pol I) was the first DNA polymerase discovered. Why was it initially misleading to consider it the main replicative polymerase in E. coli?
options: DNA Pol I was too fast to be the replicative polymerase
Mutants lacking DNA Pol I (polA mutants) could still replicate their chromosome, demonstrating that another polymerase (Pol III) performs the bulk of replication
DNA Pol I could not use dNTPs as substrates
DNA Pol I was found only in eukaryotes, not prokaryotes
questions.explanation: Arthur Kornberg purified DNA Pol I from E. coli in 1956 and demonstrated that it could synthesize DNA in vitro, earning him the Nobel Prize in 1959. For years, it was assumed to be the main replicative polymerase. However, in 1969, John Cairns and Paula De Lucia isolated a mutant (polA1) that had less than 1% of normal Pol I activity but could still replicate its chromosome normally. This demonstrated that Pol I was NOT the main replicative enzyme. The actual replicative polymerase, DNA Pol III, was subsequently identified by Thomas Kornberg (Arthur's son) and Malcolm Gefter. Pol I actually plays specialized roles: (1) removing RNA primers and filling gaps during Okazaki fragment maturation (using its unique 5'-to-3' exonuclease and polymerase activities), (2) participating in DNA repair (gap filling in NER and BER), and (3) processing damaged replication forks. The polA1 mutants were viable but UV-sensitive and showed delayed joining of Okazaki fragments, consistent with these specialized roles. This story illustrates an important principle: being the most abundant enzyme in the cell does not necessarily mean being the most important for a particular process.

questions.question: Cockayne syndrome (CS) is caused by mutations in CSA or CSB genes and is characterized by UV sensitivity and developmental abnormalities but NOT increased cancer risk. This is because CS specifically affects:
options: Global genome NER, which scans the entire genome for damage
Mismatch repair in all genomic regions
Transcription-coupled nucleotide excision repair (TC-NER), which repairs lesions on the transcribed strand of active genes, leading to cell death of damaged cells rather than mutagenesis
DNA replication fidelity only
questions.explanation: Cockayne syndrome illustrates the distinction between two sub-pathways of NER: global genome NER (GG-NER) and transcription-coupled NER (TC-NER). GG-NER scans the entire genome for helix-distorting lesions (using XPC-RAD23B for damage recognition). TC-NER specifically repairs lesions on the transcribed strand of active genes that block RNA polymerase II. When RNAPII stalls at a lesion, CSB (Cockayne syndrome B protein, an SWI/SNF-like ATPase) and CSA (a WD40-repeat protein in an E3 ubiquitin ligase complex) are recruited to initiate TC-NER, displacing the stalled polymerase and recruiting the core NER machinery. In CS patients, TC-NER is defective but GG-NER is intact. This means: (1) Damage in transcribed genes persists, blocking transcription and triggering apoptosis (explaining UV sensitivity and developmental problems). (2) Damage in non-transcribed regions is still repaired by GG-NER, preventing mutation accumulation. (3) The preferential cell death (rather than mutagenic survival) explains why CS patients do NOT have increased cancer risk, unlike XP patients where GG-NER deficiency leads to mutation accumulation.

questions.question: Nucleoside analogs like azidothymidine (AZT) are used to treat HIV infection. AZT acts as a chain terminator because:
options: After incorporation by reverse transcriptase, AZT's 3'-azido group cannot form a phosphodiester bond with the next nucleotide, halting viral DNA synthesis
AZT prevents the virus from attaching to host cell receptors
AZT degrades the viral RNA genome before it can be reverse transcribed
AZT activates the immune system to destroy infected cells
questions.explanation: AZT (azidothymidine, zidovudine) is a thymidine analog where the 3'-hydroxyl group is replaced by an azido (-N3) group. Like all nucleoside analogs used as antivirals, AZT must first be phosphorylated by cellular kinases to its triphosphate form (AZT-TP) to be active. AZT-TP competes with natural dTTP for incorporation into growing DNA chains by HIV reverse transcriptase. Once incorporated, the azido group at the 3' position cannot serve as a nucleophile for the next phosphodiester bond formation (similar to ddNTPs in Sanger sequencing), terminating chain elongation. AZT preferentially inhibits HIV reverse transcriptase over human DNA polymerases for two reasons: (1) reverse transcriptase has a more open active site that accommodates the azido group more readily during incorporation; (2) human DNA polymerases have proofreading exonuclease activity that can excise the incorporated AZT (reverse transcriptase lacks this).
